behaviours.description: Due to the COVID19 pandemic swimmers may need to book a swimming session time online, by the phone, or in person at reception.
Swimmers may want to check on what times and days a suitable swimming session is running by looking at the swimming pool's website or by making a telephone call to the swimming pool.
Swimmers may want to check the cost of swimming on the swimming pool's website or by making a telephone call to the swimming pool.
During the COVID19 pandemic swimmers may need to wear their swimming costume or swimming trunks under their clothes, to minimise the amount of time spent in the changing room at the swimming pool.

During the COVID19 pandemic swimmers need to wear a face covering (unless exempt) when they are in the reception and changing room of the swimming pool, and when they are walking between the two. (A face covering does not need to be worn when swimming).
Swimmers may need to queue at the reception of the swimming pool, if there are swimmers waiting in front of them.
Swimmers will need to pay (unless they have a membership card) for each swimming session. (This could be an adult/child/disabled swimming session). Swimmers may want to keep the receipt.
Swimmers pushing into the queue at reception.
Going to swim in the pool without paying.
Swimmers will go to the relevant changing room (men's or women's or sometimes mixed) to change out of their clothes and into their swimwear (a swimming costume or swimming trunks).

Swimmers will get changed before and after leaving the pool either in a private cubicle or in the main changing room. If swimmers decided to get changed in the main changing room swimmers will minimise the time that they don't have clothes on and will try to ensure that private parts of the body are covered by clothes or a towel.
Swimmers put their belongings into lockers, which typically require payment (which you may get back when you return to your locker). Swimmers will get a wristband with a key to their locker.
Swimmers may shower or rinse themself, in their swimwear or using a private cubicle, using the changing room showers before entering the pool. (During the COVID19 pandemic this may not be possible).
After swimming, swimming may shower themselves, in their swimwear or using a private cubicle, using the changing room showers. (During the COVID19 pandemic this may not be possible).
Not having the correct change for the locker.
Running in the changing room.
Persistenly looking at other people's bodies whilst they are getting changed.
Swimmers need to listen to and follow the direction of the lifeguards.
Swimmers enter and exit the pool using the pool steps
Swimmers who need aids to swim (e.g. arm bands) or who are not confident swimmers need to stay in the shallow area of the main pool or the smaller pool, unless taking park in a swimming lesson.
If swimmers are swimming in lanes, swimmers need to choose a lane speed suitable for how fast they are swimming.
When swimming in lanes, swimmers need to swim in the direction indicated by the sign at the end of the lane.
If swimmers need to go to the toilet whilst swimming, swimmers exit the pool, and go to the toilets in the changing rooms.
Swimmers should wait 48 hours after an incidence of diarrhoea or vomitting before going swimming.
Swimmers should make space for other swimmers, whenever possible.
Eating or drinking in the swimming pool.
Running at the poolside.
Shouting in the swimming pool.
Swimming if under the influence of alcohol or drugs.
Diving
Rough play.
